caseTitle: REPUBLIC v THE NATIONAL HOUSE OF CHIEFS EX-PARTE ODENEHO
summary: This Supreme Court of Ghana decision arose from a chieftaincy dispute involving Odeneho Akrofa Krukoko II, who claimed rightful status as Omanhene of the Wassa Fiase Traditional Area. After multiple legal battles, including contempt convictions later overturned, his name was removed from the National Register of Chiefs and replaced with Osagyefo Kwamena Enimil VI. Odeneho sought mandamus to compel the National House of Chiefs to reinstate his name. The High Court granted leave, but the Court of Appeal dismissed the application, citing procedural defects and res judicata from a prior dismissed motion. The Supreme Court allowed the appeal, clarifying that mandamus is founded on demand and refusal, with the limitation period starting from refusal. It held that interlocutory rulings do not bar subsequent actions unless they resolve the merits, and that the Court of Appeal's prior decision in Ex Parte Faibil III was per incuriam. The Court emphasized that Order 59 r.3 applied only to certiorari, not mandamus, and reversed the Court of Appeal’s judgment.
verdict: Appeal allowed. The Supreme Court reversed the Court of Appeal’s decision and reinstated the High Court’s jurisdiction to hear the mandamus application on its merits.
citations: In re Sekyedumase Stool: Nyame v Kese alias Konto [1998-99] SCGLR 476
Conca Engineering Ltd. v Moses [1984-86] 2 GLR 319

Dahabieh v SA Turqui & Bros [2001-2002] SCGLR 498
Rep. v National House of Chiefs & Ors; Ex Parte Faibil III & Ors [1984-86] 2 GLR 731
rationaleHighlights: Mandamus requires demand and refusal, with time limit running from refusal, not demand.
Interlocutory rulings generally do not attract res judicata unless they decide merits.
Court of Appeal not strictly bound by its own decisions and may depart from per incuriam rulings.
Order 59 r.3 LN 140A applies to certiorari, not mandamus.
Prior dismissal of mandamus application without demand-refusal basis does not create issue estoppel.
